"Dreaming of Systems So Perfect That No One Will Need to Be Good": Irving Babbitt and the Dangers of Humanitarianism

Justin D. Garrison

Irving Babbitt (1865-1933) was a professor of comparative literature at Harvard, and he was at the forefront of the early twentieth century American New Humanism movement. He counted Nobel Prize winning poet T.S. Eliot among his students. He had a prominent public voice in his day and wrote widely on topics including imagination, higher education, political theory, and practical American politics. One of his enduring topics of concern was analyzing the ideational and imaginative dimensions of what he called "humanitarianism" in modern and American political thought and practice.

For Babbitt, humanitarianism came in two distinct though complementary strains. The first he called "scientific humanitarianism" and the second he called "sentimental humanitarianism." Although scientific humanitarianism tends to place more emphasis upon rationality than the sentimental type, both versions are highly imaginative, that is, appeal to and seek to change a person’s pre-conceptual sense of how reality holds together and what in politics is truly possible. Both versions of humanitarianism reject the notion that human nature consists to some degree or another of permanent moral imperfection. Hence, the humanitarians see politics as a program, not of cultivating individual ethical restraint, but of emancipating humanity from its poorly-organized, confining, and even evil past. Scientific humanitarians tend to organize projects of political liberation around the promotion and instantiation of "scientific" or "rational" arrangements that maximize individual physical security and opportunities for material comfort. Partly in reaction to the perceived sterile rationality of scientific humanitarians, those of the sentimental type champion a transformative politics built on emotional and "romantic" appeals to liberty, equality, unity, and justice. Babbitt counted Enlightenment figures such as Francis Bacon, Thomas Hobbes, and John Locke as representative scientific humanitarians; he believed Jean-Jacques Rousseau, the first major critic of the Enlightenment, was the arch-typical sentimental humanitarian.

This chapter analyzes humanitarianism as Babbitt understood it both in its modern and American manifestations. It also explains why Babbitt was deeply troubled by the theories and practical fruits associated with this movement. For Babbitt, humanitarians of the scientific and sentimental types fundamentally misunderstood the human condition and thus supported a politics inclined toward individual moral chaos and tremendous national and international violence. Most vividly in his own life, he believed the two pillars of humanitarianism made significant contributions to the outbreak and inhumane conduct of World War I. The ideas and imaginative disposition driving humanitarianism remain alive and well. Thus, understanding Babbitt’s critique of this movement in his own time will shed much needed light on the disorders of the present as well as ways to work toward a reconstitution of individual and social order along the lines of Babbitt’s preferred "humanistic" alternative to humanitarianism.
